body.p:
I can very readily excuse
you for what I began to think was a little piece
of neglect on your part in delaying to write me a long
note that I know what was the cause one which I
regalled much to hear,! Hebrew you are not to ?
yourself for a Hebrew It is true that in no period
of their existence nationally, did our brethren stand in greater
need of instruction and of being aroused to a due sense of their
duty than now, and therefore, I still continue to say Hebrew
but do not let your health suffer by so doing, why not take
a little recreation? Why not take a trip into Montreal this summer?
Do you wait for a formal invitation? Here is one for you there
“The Rev Abraham deSola sees also many other friends will be most
happy to see the Rev Isaac Leeser in Montreal during the present
summer, when, should the Rev. I L. determine upon coming, they
will will endeavor to make the arrangements which
will enable him to pass his time as pleasurably as it is possible
to do in so outlandish a place ” Please excuse the pink edged
not paper, but seriously, dear Friend, I think that a trip to
Canada would do you much good, and I shall be delighted to see
you, to find you a room, to show you my books, and (probably)
to grovel with you over their contents.

Receive my best thanks for your kindness in inserting the long
notice of my lecture, I have not the least doubt as to the party
who sent it, He is an esteemed friend of mine, and one I believe
with whom you are also well acquainted but as you don't
mention names I shall not.

You misunderstand me as regards the Hebrew. My object was
to publish it in the same way as English's book was republished
in Jamaica It would have been an anonymous publication—
this I think I neglected to tell you, as I write in haste, My
object was further, to ? from you as the person most
able to inform me, whether there were reading Israelites enough
in America to pay for the printing of the book, not to
make it a course of profit, that of course I would not expect.
I know as well as you (excuse nay indulgence) that neither
pudding nor fame was to be derived from it, but such

is my estimation of the work, that I think it would do
a great deal of good, were it generally known. I did not at all
expect, my dear Friend, that you would gather subscriptions
To repeat your own words “That figure is out of the question.”
I only ? open for what you have readily given me
your advise, and co-operation. Many thanks for your
? as to fishing in troubled waters. I am well convinced
I can assure you of the value & truth of what you say, but in
case of being attacked by some of our christian friends (which I
think would be unlikely, the publication being anonymous
I would always be in possession of the ? provide) by some
? of controversial writers on our side the auction so that
at all events I should have the means if not the capability to
give them drubbing for drubbing. I have no wish however as
I know my own (insufficiency, to enter into controversial
disputation, and if I desired to give to the public some of my
translations as my own and which I have by me I
certainly would not choose the Hebrew but rather my humble
renderings of our Rabbinical writers, I am more attached to them
than to Lituanian? Caraibes? and always was so. Tell me, how
would you like to receive some of these translations for
publication in the Occident, and then, before the matter is distributed
print off seperately, say 500 copies of them I paying the difference
and receiving the books or you takeing those with me in the profits
and leaving the proportionate expense. The difference could not
be very great as there would be but little alteration to be
made in the matter before it is distributed and merely
the expense of paper & press work. I am sure I could dispose
of many in England ?. I have promised to
contribute to the Occident and I don't know why one should
not derive mutual benefit from the course first proposed—

Please understand me, I do not mean that the Hebrew should
so appear, but smaller works such as the Hebrew
Hebrew translations of
which I have made although not completed. Dont think
either that it is a mania for printing which leads me
to propose this but receive it as a casual thought the
value and practicability of which you are yourself to
determine in your next communication. But let me

remind you, that selections from the writings of Maimonides were
published by Bernard, though not those which I have.
The book sold well among christians and even among Jews
no doubt because the author was a chestiuvuad?.

You will ere this have received the first instalment of my
promised article on the settlement of the Jews in England. It
is a dark subject and perhaps you and your readers may say
a profitable one, but it is one which I was compelled to write
in my lecture on the Jews of England and you have it in ?
form. The Sermon or the Hebrew you will perceive is
one of a series therefore if you have not already published
it and will press it back a month or so, inducting the
Enquiry “instead, I will send you one or two others on the
same subject. With the 2nd instalment of the “Enquiry” some
you you will have enough of my scribbles has at least
3 Occidents to come i.e. If you reckon the Sermon and
publish the instalments separately if you print them
together pray let me know for I am quite in the dark as to your
proceedings as we get the Occidents so late here, but not
here only. Why should Mrs Joel of London say she had not
received any for the last 3 months. Prenez garde, Monsieur le
Redacteur! Thanks for the aptra? she sent me. I shall
(in return/) expect the same favor every time any papers of
mine may be inserted. I send you a report (or rather a
digest of one since it would be inconvenient to send so much
paper, of the first years operations of our society. If you
dont feel inclined to publish all the ? names
it contains, pray do not, but just say 'an those will that
“there follow the names” The committees wanted to give the people enough
but I think the feel stated should be quite sufficient. I am quite pleased with Mrs Jacob
Joseph, lately arrived among us, and indeed so
are all here. She is extremely amiable and intelligent
I regret much that I have not been able to see her
as often as I could wish. Preuis? le temps viendra
Pray do not allow so long & time to intervene

before writing again By the way, your letter is dated
1st June and I did not receive it till the 27th with
the Occidents. Stand when you write, write fully.

Now dear friend farewell for the present
with earnest prayers for your perfect health and
general welfare believe me

A lady (Miss Miriam Belisario) formerly a pupil
of mine has lately published a Hebrew & English ?
advertised in the day to Jewish papers as Hebrew & he
she wishes that she has sent me a copy, but
having entrusted it to some person to ? me, who
was going out to Canada I have not yet seen it.
I would otherwise have written a review (for the sake of
old acquaintanceship) for the Occident. If you feel
disposed to resign the post of honor, or dont intend
writing one, pray send me the books per first
opportunity and I will endeavor to do the
needful.
